dialogues.speaker: UNIVERSAL TRADEMARK
dialogues.text: accompanied by newsreel theme music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An anti-Nazi demonstration takes place in the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hindenburg is coming again -- that’s what ait the excitement is about. The pride of Germany is due _here on the morning of May 6.

dialogues.speaker: WINDOW DISPLAY
dialogues.text: Camera ‘briefly explores a window display guarded by a po man. (See Appendix #1) No representations of the Hindenbu herself are shown. :

dialogues.speaker: NEWSREEL VOICE
dialogues.text: During the 1937 season the giant airship is scheduled to make 18 round trips from Frankfurt to ra . Lakehurst, New Jersey. * . FAST MONTAGE ~- OLD DRAWINGS, LITHOGRAPHS, ETC. starting with the Montgolfier balloon.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSREEL VOICE
dialogues.text: A hundred and fifty years ago two Frenchmen, the Montgolfier brothers, made the first controlled flight in a hot-air balloon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: using the same style. (See Appendix #2.)

dialogues.speaker: NEWSREEL VOICE
dialogues.text: Soon the discovery of hydrogen put the birds in competition with a steam-propelled banana, an eighty- foot cigar, several flying bolognas, and a tremendous lemon seed operat- ing on gravity and gall.

dialogues.speaker: COUNT ZEPPELIN'S ACCOMPLISHMENTS 7
dialogues.text: Old photos and film (stock) of the Count and his early Zeppelins: Schwaben, Viktoria Luise, Hansa, Sachsen, Bode

dialogues.speaker: NEWSREEL VOICE
dialogues.text: At the turn of the century, Count Ferdinand von Zeppelin flew a 400- foot sausage powered by two marine engines for twenty miles. After this triumph, Germany gave full support to the old Count. He and his young associate, Dr. Hugo Eckener, founded the world's first passenger airline. 8 SEQUENCE OF LZ 126 ~ 8. Stock film showing her overseas flight, delivery on Ameri soil, her landing on an aircraft carrier, and her flight the Panama Canal.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSREEL VOICE
dialogues.text: In 1924 the Zeppelin Company built the LZ 126 for the U.S. Navy. Re- christened the Los Angeles, she made air history under her brilliant commander, Charles E. Rosendahl. But no other country has equalled ~ Germany's phenomenal success in the field of lighter-than-air transpor- tation.

dialogues.speaker: SEQUENCE OF. GRAF ZEPPELIN
dialogues.text: showing her voyages to South America, her trip around the world, etc.

dialogues.speaker: TT
dialogues.text: aN . NEWSREEL VOICE For ten years the old Graf Zeppelin has flown over a million miles an carried 13,000 passengers without the slightest injury to a single one. : .

dialogues.speaker: SEQUENCE OF HINDENBURG UNDER CONSTRUCTION 10
dialogues.text: at Friedrichshafen. In addition to stock film, this mater will include drawings, plans, cross-sections, etc., makin clear the various features of the Zeppelin.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSREEL VOICE
dialogues.text: Now the Zeppelin Company and German genius have created the airship supreme, the Hindenburg. She is the climax of man's dream to con- quer the air, the new Queen of the Skies. A final B&W photo shows the great airship in her hangar i last stages of construction. As main title music swells..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The above phdto now comes to life showing the dirigible:i 2 her color and glory. In the f.g. the sun strikes: the h black swastikas on her tail. . MAIN TITLE FADES. IN OVER: —

dialogues.speaker: THE HINDENBURG
dialogues.text: 11-a INT. THE EMPTY HULL OF THE HINDENBURG - DAY ~- MATTE . , Credits continue over. The interior suggests a cathed like vastness. Aluminum arches, girders, webs of wire soa upwards to the vaulted fabric roof. . An initial gas cell starts to inflate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An awesome sight, she turns gracefully in the sky. During after the abbreviated credits that follow, the sky turns dreamlike. The Hindenburg recedes, begins to disappear in mist, until there is only empty sky. Music continues over

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A title flashes on: MILWAUKEE, APRIL 17, 1937. Vo oe ee. - oe  15 16 17 18 19 20 21

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A middle-aged woman, she looks down as if writing.

dialogues.speaker: THE LETTER
dialogues.text: in German. Two words at the end of the line Kathie finish are plain enough: "Zeppelin Hindenburg....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A title: GERMAN EMBASSY, APRIL 21, 1937.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: held in a man's hand.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN AMBASSADOR LUTHER
dialogues.text: A small, white~haired, old-world diplomat in spats, he sh the letter to his First Secretary.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST SECRETARY
dialogues.text: (unimpressed) The Embassy got hundreds of letters like sthat last year, Mr. Ambassador. Mostly from cranks. The new season's beginning, naturally we can expect more of the same. .

dialogues.speaker: LUTHER
dialogues.text: : (worriedly) Mrs. Rauch's letter is different. It's specific. She spells out how and where the Zeppelin will be destroyed, ° . (tapping ‘letter) A time bomb over American territory.

dialogues.speaker: SHOCK CUT TO
dialogues.text: GROUND-TO-AIR SHOT - A JU 87 “STUKA" DIVE BOMBER diving toward earth, its propeller-driven siren screaming

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A title: BERLIN, APRIL 30, 1937. The Stuka lands, taxis to the flight line. The engine is 14 15° 16 17 18 19 20 21  dv #02075 5

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In flying helmet, white silk scarf and three-quarter leng coat, he climbs from the cockpit. Kessler, in his forties is seemingly all meat and stone with a strong, grim face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Luftwaffe General and Colonel jump from a command car a embrace him warmly. GENERAL ‘ (grinning) Showing us how you do it in Spain?

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: (with an edge) I don't do much flying there.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Good to have you back, Franz. We heard they're giving you a Knight's . Cross to your Iron Cross.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: For writing up dossiers, I suppose. “ (significantly) Half the time about our own people. > ‘(lew; taking . - General aside) They're turning us into a Gestapo, Karl. I want you to get me out of Intelligence. Give me back my old Reconnaissance command. sx.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL
dialogues.text: (uncomfortably) That might not be so easy, Franz. yo KESSLER . Why not? All you have to do is: . sign the order. .

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL
dialogues.text: (evasively) You've been brought back for a slight probiem we've inherited. - Kessler looks at him, frowning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A title: MINISTRY OF PROPAGANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eyes down, he reads the Rauch letter.

dialogues.speaker: A VOICE
dialogues.text: Furthermore, Colonel Kessler, that 2 letter confirms our own suspicions that there's a plot to sabotage the LZ 129 on this flight. Angle widens to include Goebbels watching Kessler astutel from behind his big desk. .

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: (returning letter) Then obviously, Dr. Goebbels, the sane thing to do is cancel the flight until the Gestapo uncovers the plot.

dialogues.speaker: GOEBBELS
dialogues.text: Sane, perhaps, but weak. The prop- aganda value of the LZ 129 is highly important.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Well, from a military standpoint she's a flying dinosaur.

dialogues.speaker: GOEBBELS
dialogues.text: . (annoyed) . Colonel, the LZ 129 is a world symbol of Nazi power. You should be honored you've been chosen to guard her safety.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: My field is the estimation of enemy air operations. It's not espionage. GOEBBELS . . . A Zeppelin ride should be a vacation compared to Spain. You're being -- loaned, shall .we say, to the LZ 129 . as the officer in complete charge of security for this trip. You'll have the power to arrest suspects or do anything you think necessary. But quietly, discreetly, or it might appear we have internal opposition.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: And you're afraid it could strengthen the Resistance Movement.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: iv #02075 7 TT \ 25° CONTINUED . 25 a, GOEBBELS (sharply) _ There is no resistance movement, Colonel. _¢

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER,
dialogues.text: That's reassuring to hear from the Minister of Propaganda.

dialogues.speaker: GOEBBELS
dialogues.text: (eyeing him; rising) I mustn't keep you from your next appointment. (walking to door) Let's hope you'll change your opinion of our ‘flying dinosaur.'

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Perhaps I will -- unless there's an egg hatching in her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black-uniformed Gestapo Major Hufschmidt moves past the b

dialogues.speaker: . HUF SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: . (pointing) A bellows bomb detonated by atmos- pheric pressure. Found on the Graf. Zeppelin. . : Angle widens to include Kessler bepind Hufschmidt. ” Belo street level, the room resembles a small museum. Hufschmi conducts Kessler past a display of time bombs. men

dialogues.speaker: HUFSCHMIDT
dialogues.text: «.eA radio bomb discovered on Himmler's plane...A chemical fuse bomb from the hold of the steamship Bremen...A clockwork incendiary, . Small but, could easily ignite : . hydrogen...

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: I've only seen one smaller. A British device with a silent acid fuse. Blew up a locomotive in the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to a diagram) ~~ The Hindenburg's being searched twice a day from stem to stern. I guaran- tee you'll board a clean ship.

dialogues.speaker: TY 26 CONTINUED . 26
dialogues.text: / HUFSCHMIDT (Cont'd) (facing him) But what happens on the flight is your responsibility, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ed

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Also an honor, I've been told.

dialogues.speaker: HUFSCHMIDT
dialogues.text: (handing him a leather notebook) This is a dossier we've prepared on your fellow passengers and crew. You'll find it useful.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: (perusing notebook) Ninety-seven people.

dialogues.speaker: HUFSCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Including you, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Well then, only ninety-six to worry ii about. That makes it simpler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A title: FRANKFURT

dialogues.speaker: THE ZEPPELIN COMPANY, MAY 1, 1937
dialogues.text: : ’ A man and a woman approach and stop at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kessler, now in civilian clothes, kisses his attractive brunette good-bye and enters the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Ernst Lehmann and Dr. Hugo Eckener, both in civil clothes, read the Rauch letter as Kessler faces them. Leh fifty-one, is a quietly forceful man of short, stocky bui Eckener, sixty-eight, a gcateed visionary, is the greates living pioneer of lighter-than-air transportation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a glint of anger, Lehmann tosses down the letter.

dialogues.speaker: LEHMANN
dialogues.text: The Hindenburg is scheduled to leave in two days, Colonel. Why did your Gestapo wait till now to show us this?

dialogues.speaker: ECKENER
dialogues.text: It's inexcusable that our passengers have to make other travel arrange- ments this late.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: The flight hasn't been cancelled. ‘ LEHMANN Not cancelled? (gesturing at letter) I thought -- Why are you here? KESSLER . I'll be aboard as a Special Security Officer. I want you with me, Captain Lehmann, as a Senior Airship Observer.

dialogues.speaker: . LEHMANN
dialogues.text: You may have to work with the Gestapo, Colonel, but I don't.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Dr. Eckener, you built the Hindenburg. Don't you want to protect your interests?

dialogues.speaker: ECKENER
dialogues.text: I've protected them for forty years by taking no risks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if I wanted to go, you'd never be able to clear it. Dr. Eckener . : and: I are out of favor at the Chancellery.

dialogues.speaker: ECKENER
dialogues.text: I refused to name the Hindenburg after the Austrian Corporal.

dialogues.speaker: LEHMANN
dialogues.text: Captain Pruss, the new commander, is an excellent airshipman -- and a good Nazi.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LEHMANN (Cont'd) (7 : (returning letter) NS Don't embarrass yourself by request- ing me, Colonel. There's no way they'd allow it.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: (pocketing letter) There's a way. I'll see you at the airfield Monday. Lehmann and Eckener look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A title: FRANKFURT AIRFIELD, SUNDAY, MAY 2, 1937 In this dimly lit, smoky rathskeller near the airfield, s of the crew, their wives and girlfriends are having a far party around tables pushed together: Chief Rigger Knorr, squat, long-armed man of fifty with a homely sympathetic Frau Knorr, his broad-beamed, narrow-minded wife; Steward Imhof, a martinet; compact, tough Elevatorman Felber; Sec Rigger Neuhaus, a country boy; rugged Mechanic Ludecke; H man Frenkel, meticulous in dress and manner. om First Rigger Eric Boerth and Freda Halle, a busty, han blonde a few years older than Boerth, behave openly as lo Boerth is a youthful man with a determined face, close-cr hair and a tall athletic build. He is a mixture of extrem » competence, readiness to serve and tight-lipped superio « -a character more complex than he himself realizes.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF RIGGER KNORR
dialogues.text: ==Stupid. SS men crawling all over our ship morning till night. Dirt from their shoes.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST RIGGER BOERTH
dialogues.text: If we put an elephant in the hull they couldn't find it. >

dialogues.speaker: . ELEVATORMAN FELBER
dialogues.text: They weren't looking for an elephant.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND RIGGER NEUHAUS
dialogues.text: Did you see Eric when the SS dog barked? He jumped ten feet and the dog bit him in- the brains -- here. (points to backside)

dialogues.speaker: BOERTH
dialogues.text: (joining laughter) Better than being bitten by the ss. He playfully bites Freda on the neck. : .

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER , 32
dialogues.text: In civilian clothes (always from now on) he sits at a sid table with the slender brunette, Eleanore, his wife. She stares at a garish calendar-art oil painting of the Hinde on the wall. He touches her hand comfortingly. :

dialogues.speaker: ELEANORE
dialogues.text: You should've refused to go on that Wagnerian whale.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Ssh. (lightly; glancing off) The crew might think I'm Jonah.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANORE
dialogues.text: I can't bear it...Alfred, then Spain, and now this... “ (urgently) We're not far from Switzerland, Franz. I-.was walking along the river today and thinking that if- we could only --- . ‘

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: No. :

dialogues.speaker: ELEANORE
dialogues.text: You despise what you're doing now. KESSLER. What would you have me do in Switzerland? What would I tekl them -- Yesterday ‘I was a Colonel in the German Air Force...? It would be different if we weré Jews or pacifists, or even Communists.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANORE
dialogues.text: We must get away, Franz. While we're still young enough to pick up the pieces.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: I can't. I'd be a deserter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: mp 32 7 33 Sees

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 32
dialogues.text: KESSLER (Cont'd) (gripping her hand) Listen, Eleanore. I talked to Karl. He said he'll try to get me back my old group. We'd live . in the south, far from Berlin.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANORE
dialogues.text: (touching his face) Poor Franz. They even make your dreams lie to you. She looks at him with compassion and turns away. He focus his attention on the noisy airshipmen.

dialogues.speaker: CREW TABLE
dialogues.text: Boerth and Ludecke, arms interlocked and holding two-lite steins, engage in a chug-a-lug contest. The other crewmen pound the table counting to ten. Freda pushes down Boerth stein. - :

dialogues.speaker: FREDA
dialogues.text: You'll be drunk, Eric.

dialogues.speaker: . LUDECKE
dialogues.text: “We'll be dry for two days on board, woman.

dialogues.speaker: FREDA
dialogues.text: (tender and sexy) Please, Eric. Not tonight. Boerth kisses her long and hard. The others start an even more uproarious countdown.

dialogues.speaker: STEWARDESS IMHOF
dialogues.text: (pulling. them apart) Behave yourselves. You act liké gypsies. . . . Frau Knorr nods agreement and glares at the lovers. Now uncomfortable, Freda whispers to Boerth. He rises and sta out with her, carrying his stein. : :

dialogues.speaker: BOERTH
dialogues.text: (hoisting stein) Good night, good night. (a bow to Imhof) We're going to bed, Stewardess. We'll ring if we need anything.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 33
dialogues.text: Much laughter and rolling of eyes. Draining his beer as h goes, Boerth bumps Kessler's table.

dialogues.speaker: BOERTH
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I'm just a poor gypsy. Kessler nods pleasantly. Boerth follows Freda out.

dialogues.speaker: . FRAU KNORR
dialogues.text: Freda Halle is a loose woman. They say she works for foreigners, some ‘French bank in Frankfurt.

dialogues.speaker: FELBER
dialogues.text: (coming alert) We should report it.

dialogues.speaker: KNORR
dialogues.text: Women's gossip. We're all loyal Germans. Besides,: Eric's no fool. Enough, now. (rising for a toast) I drink to the one I love. . (as. his. Frau preens) The Hindenburg: Amid laughter and cheers, they all rise. Mechanic Ludecke starts singing the "Horst Wessel Song" and the others joi

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER. AND ELEANORE
dialogues.text: Shuddering, she releases his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ‘That song is going to make me sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A low-key atmospheric vista of the giant airship at rest the hangar. Lit from the inside, she casts an eerie green glow through her translucent belly. At a hundred feet up, curving flanks disappear into heavy shadow. SS soldiers w police dogs stand guard around the sleeping phantom. The strains of the "Horst Wessel Song" carry over...Kessler a his pale dark lady appear among the grotesque shapes of e ment on the perimeter. They stare at the vast apparition she gropes for his hand.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOMB WITH WORKS EXPOSED
dialogues.text: Held in a hand, it is a rectangle about 2" wide and 5" lo with complicated wheels and tiny gears. It is being teste In utter silence the black timer needle revolves. When it -xreadches the detonation point, it stops with a click.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: shooting toward hangar past the Hindenburg now outside at mooring mast. People, the Company transport busses, equip are dwarfed by the giant airship and her nest. Soldiers p the area, some holding leashed dogs. Occasionally they wa back spectators. A uniformed brass band pumps away on the apron, while a troop of Hitler Youth forms up beside it. A title: MONDAY, MAY 3, 1937

dialogues.speaker: HANGAR CLOCK . 39
dialogues.text: showing 6:30. Below the clock is posted in German and Eng Departure Frankfurt - 8:00 P.M. May 3 Arrival Lakehurst - 6:00 A.M. May 6 ff w/

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - -An atmosphere of intense activity and excitement...Bag , being delivered and freight moved out. - ;uniformed Zep Company officials bustling back and forth...well-wishers chattering with passengers....

dialogues.speaker: BAGGAGE SECTION . 42
dialogues.text: SS men make the passengers uneasy with an almost microsco inspection of their baggage. * . fouRISTY TYPE . . . (in Tyrolean hat) What's going on? Something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: SWEET-FACED OLD LADY
dialogues.text: I'm not smuggling anything, I promise.

dialogues.speaker: . SS MAN
dialogues.text: ae Standard procedure for Zeppelins.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER 43
dialogues.text: on the fringe, appraising his fellow passengers.

dialogues.speaker: HIS POINT OF VIEW
dialogues.text: Reed and Bess Channing sip champagne with Hattie, a hands woman of sixty-odd who has brought a bon voyage basket wi champagne and caviar. Reed Channing, mid-forties, relaxed urbane, is impeccably groomed. His wife Bess, forty, is southern, uninhibited, warm and basically genteel. She po champagne into an ashtray for her Dalmation.

dialogues.speaker: HATTIE
dialogues.text: (Texas accent) I wish you'd forget this Zeppelin crap and come on over to the Coronation. Quacky's rented a Duke's palace or somethin' outside London.

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: Not us, Hattie. Reed's show starts rehearsals the twelfth.

dialogues.speaker: CHANNING
dialogues.text: Anyway British quarantine won't let Heidi into the country. ‘HATTIE You should've had children instead of dogs. ’ Channing and Bess exchange a look. Bess gives him a nod CHANNING . (twinkling) The evil spell's been lifted. Bess is, pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: HATTIE
dialogues.text: At your age? .

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: (nodding) Finally. CHANNING. But no rooftop announcements just yet. °We don't want to push our luck.

dialogues.speaker: HATTIE
dialogues.text: (hugging her) Oh, Bess....

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER , 44-A
dialogues.text: shifting his attention to:  sk #02075 16

dialogues.speaker: 44-B THE IMMIGRATION DESK 44-B
dialogues.text: Under the supervision of SS officers, passengers are chec through Immigration. As each passenger is cleared, his pa port is given to Watch Officer Dimmler who places it in a strongbox. The passenger is then body-searched by Chief Steward Kirsch or Steward Macher, with Stewardess Imhof a ing to the ladies in a small curtained booth. All matches lighters are removed and placed in bags labelled with the sengers' names.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 44-C ANGLE ON THE COUNTESS VON SCHARNWITZ 44-c Elegant in a striking white cape, she hands the Immigrati official her passport.. A woman of great style and breedi with a finely chiseled face, the Countess is a classic be

dialogues.speaker: IMMIGRATION OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: (studying passport) How long will you be away from us, Countess? He eyes a Gestapo Major who glides over.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTESS
dialogues.text: (a charming smile) Until I get homesick, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: GESTAPO MAJOR
dialogues.text: (uncharmed; tak- oe Me ' ing passport) : . 2 What is the purpose of your trip? :

dialogues.speaker: COUNTESS
dialogues.text: To visit my daughter at school in _. _ Boston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He registers interest in this. a 2 44-E TWO SHOT - THE COUNTESS AND GESTAPO MAJOR a 7 44-8

dialogues.speaker: GESTAPO MAJOR
dialogues.text: Where will you be staying?

dialogues.speaker: COUNTESS
dialogues.text: . With friends. Mr. and Mrs. Alden - 3 Winthrop.

dialogues.speaker: . GESTAPO MAJOR
dialogues.text: [ In Boston?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: sk

dialogues.speaker: 44-E
dialogues.text: Vo

dialogues.speaker: COUNTESS
dialogues.text: Yes -- and their place on Cape Cod.

dialogues.speaker: GESTAPO MAJOR
dialogues.text: What does he do, his occupation? . @

dialogues.speaker: COUNTESS
dialogues.text: (with an edge) He's with the Winthrop First National Bank and I can assure you, Major, he's not the doorman.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER 44-P
dialogues.text: smiling at the Countess' answer and the Major's reaction.

dialogues.speaker: A PAGE BOY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Mr. Edward Douglas.... Kessler turns.

dialogues.speaker: PAGE BOY . 45
dialogues.text: carrying a cablegram. “ PAGE BOY Mr. Douglas.... Douglas, a trim, prematurely gray man, intercepts the cab ‘As he'reads it Kessler drifts closer, trying for a casua squint at the text, but Douglas promptly stuffs the cable his pocket. He looks at the hangar clock and carefully se his Patek Philippe. Kessler checks his own Luftwaffe chro meter and smiles at Douglas.. —

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Seems we'll get off a little late.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Yeah, what's the holdup? * (moving to Immigration Desk) Let's get this show on the road. Kessler gets in line behind Douglas. At the head of the l flashbulbs are discovered on Otto Vogel. Suave, attractiv Vogel maintains a smiling presence. Kirsch turns the bulb over to the Gestapo Major. Vogel shrugs it off.

dialogues.speaker: GESTAPO MAJOR
dialogues.text: The official photographer should . know better. As Douglas is searched by Macher, Kessler steps up to Kir The Gestapo Major beckons Kessler through without a searc

dialogues.speaker: GESTAPO MAJOR
dialogues.text: Not required for you, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: (handing him lighter) It should be.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT BRESLAU 46
dialogues.text: A prosperous American executive, he shepherds his family four into line: wife Mildred, overdressed and a social cl his pretty, somewhat scatterbrained eighteen-year-old dau Irene; his two mischievous boys, Paul, ten, and Peter, ei Breslau, holding five passports and fidgety Peter's hand, drops the passports. Kessler helps Him gather them up.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: (returning passports) Your name is familiar, Mr. Breslau. _ Do you have relatives in Germany?

dialogues.speaker: BRESLAU
dialogues.text: »Many friends and associates, but no relatives.

dialogues.speaker: MILDRED
dialogues.text: You might have, Albert. == (to Kessler) I'm sure our name once had a’‘'von'. Von Breslau. Prussian nobility.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Ah, that's where I heard it. . BRESLAU a co . (kidding wife) : Too bad, Mildred. The 'von' doesn't , count when you're born in the States.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: We all were.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: {tousling their heads) Couple of cowboys.

dialogues.speaker: PAJETTA AND NAPIER 47
dialogues.text: They move toward the line into the transit area.. British Major Earl Napier, 31, is turned out in the high style of Guards Officer -- brush moustache, bowler, and regimental His American companion, Emilio Pajetta, is a crusty old c mudgeon. Using. a cane, he hobbles along on Napier's.arm.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: (joining them) Handsome cane, sir. May I see it?

dialogues.speaker: PAJETTA
dialogues.text: You wouldn't admire it so much, mister, if you were crippled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't intend to be. (to an official) Tape the end of Mr. Pajetta's cane and return it to him, please. ao NAPIER I say, you must be the special security chap. Good thing too. (glancing off) Ruddy blimp's filled with hydrogen.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: (gravely) _ I'll make a note of that. (moving off) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: PAJETTA
dialogues.text: (to Napier) They call that dumb Dutchman a security man? . , ‘ , . COMPANY OFFICIAL > : {taking the cane) * The tape is for your own safety, sir. The steel tip could strike sparks.

dialogues.speaker: THE COUNTESS VON SCHARMWITZ 48
dialogues.text: Arguing with SS inspectors by her six Vuitton suitcases a large wardrobe trunk, she is the last one at the baggage

dialogues.speaker: COUNTESS
dialogues.text: I'd expect more courtesy on a cattle boat. Now you just do as you're « told. :

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: May I help, Countess?

dialogues.speaker: COUNTESS
dialogues.text: Ah, Colonel Kessler. I thought I recognized you. These people insist » on going through my entire trunk before putting it on board. Will you talk to them, please?

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Certainly. (to SS men) Open it, search it, strip the lining, remove the metal corners. If you . run out of time, ship it to the Countess on the Bremen. The SS men smile and fall to work, opening the trunk and her gowns, lingerie, etc. on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTESS
dialogues.text: (coolly but with- out rancor) Not very gallant, was it, Colonel? . The German Air Force isn't dt all what it used to be »- but then I . suppose nothing is these days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. 49 ANGLE. ON HINDENBURG - LOCATION AND MATTE “49 The gangway, a double staircase, lowers from her belly. P sengers in the transit area shuffle forward. The guard do o.s. erupt, in alarmed barking. Heads swivel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man with a suitcase and a package runs from a taxi towa the hangar, pursued by SS men with dogs. He laughs, sets down the suitcase, and comically attempts to pet the sava dogs, throwing in Nazi salutes and a goose step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kessler and the Gestapo Major hurry to him.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR
dialogues.text: Your papers, please. The man holds up a magazine with his picture on an inside page, captioned with his name, Joe Spah. The picture show him climbing a towering lamp post in his drunk act at the circus. Wiry, energetic, Spah, thirty, is a comic acrobat who aspires to better things. He comes on strong, but und neath the brashness is a decent, naively sincere man. Wit his gift for pantomime, there is about him, as with many clowns, an overall air of pathos.

dialogues.speaker: SPAH
dialogues.text: (a sleight-of- hand. trick) ‘Here's my passport and ticket all , in order. : (to SS man) Just throw the bag on the Zep, son. Kessler glances at the package which the Major takes and open: a Dresden doll. The Major inspects it, lifts the sk

dialogues.speaker: SPAH
dialogues.text: (imitating a doll) Goodie, goodie, wanna play doctor?

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Why not? (to Major) Give the doll a thorough examination -- and the syitcase. :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind a crate she fusses with a run in her stocking. A young man in Zeppelin Company uniform approaches, extendi a clipboard and a pen. YOUNG MAN oy ‘Will Miss Breslau please write down . her correct weight?. : °

dialogues.speaker: IRENE
dialogues.text: I did. A hundred and six.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: (low) Keep the pen. A present from relatives in Germany. But not a word to your father till you've sailed. He'll understand.

dialogues.speaker: IRENE
dialogues.text: But we don't have any relatives in Germany. Without answering, the young official hurries off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band on the apron switches to a Wagnerian air. The Hi Youth troop snaps to attention. Captains Pruss and Lehman approach the Zeppelin at a brisk pace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pruss is a big, bluff man with the heartiness and solemni necessary to have both the affection and respect of his c Spotting Kessler, Pruss gestures to him.

dialogues.speaker: . PRUSS
dialogues.text: Colonel Kessler, board with us. - (as he joins them) Did you know we have the pleasure of Captain Lehmann for this voyage?

dialogues.speaker: LEHMANN
dialogues.text: (quickly) Just as an observer, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as a diplomat.

dialogues.speaker: LEHMANN
dialogues.text: = - .feyeing Kessler) —~ It seems someone has arranged for me to go to Washington to. try and - get us helium. Kessler gazes back with a faint smile.

dialogues.speaker: . KESSLER
dialogues.text: I wish we had it this trip. - . The three men start up the gangway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .Now the passengers are escorted to the ship. The Countes accompanied by Chief Radio Officer Willy Speck who carrie armful of clothing from her defrocked wardrobe trunk.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: jv 55

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A stocky man in his thirties, he has a coarsely handsome The Channings follow behind their dog, carried in her cas Steward Kirsch. Pajetta, the tip of his cane now swathed white tape, hobbles along on Napier's arm.

dialogues.speaker: GANGWAY
dialogues.text: The vanguard of passengers mounts into the world of the Zeppelin. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The passengers fan out, some to their cabins, others to g exploring. Several, among them Douglas, pause by the bust von Hindenburg in the foyer. On the wall above are three clocks: the ship's clock showing 7:10; Berlin time the sa New York time 2:10 (P.M.). Below the clocks on the port s is a bulletin board, and to the starboard a large map of -voyage route with a little swastika pin-flag marking the Zeppelin's position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passengers gaze around. The walls bear a huge Mercator pr jection of the world depicting sea voyages (Columbus, Magellan, etc.), the Atlantic crossing. of the U.S. Airsh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Los Angeles, and the around-the-world flight of the Graf - Zeppelin. An aluminum baby grand stands in a corner. Spah oo strikes a note on it and goes into a hornpipe dance. Seve people laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mildred Breslau, followed by her two boys, surveys the ro Fifty feet long, it is a restaurant of luxury and refinem with paintings>of airship travel. Mildred, however, zeroe in on the china, turning it over to see the brand. 7 5

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Writing tabies, mail chute, ship's library...The sweet-fa old lady looks around surreptitiously, then steals a shea stationery. As a loudspeaker blares, she jumps.

dialogues.speaker: LOUDSPEAKER
dialogues.text: Will Mrs. Eleanore Kessler please come to the gangway. i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kessler forces his way down against the passengers still boarding. The band plays relentlessly.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANORE
dialogues.text: Escorted from the crush behind the guards, she runs to- h husband. They kiss in the shadow of the ship.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: (an urgent whisper) I had to see you again.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANORE
dialogues.text: (clinging to him) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: I think you should do what you said -«»-about going to Switzerland.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANORE
dialogues.text: (glancing at Youth Troop) Not without you. His eyes follow hers and cloud.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: All right. I'11 be home in six days. Then we'll ‘see. They exchange a long, loving look. Embracing her hurriedl he runs up the gangway which then withdraws: into the shi

dialogues.speaker: GONDOLA CLOCK
dialogues.text: which reads 8:18. Pull back to Pruss who turns from the c » « Rl Up ship: PRUSS Watch Officer. Dimmler, Chief Engineer Sauter, Helmsman F Elevatorman Felber snap to their posts.

dialogues.speaker: PRUSS
dialogues.text: (to Lehmann; gruffly) Don't. just stand there like an ob- server. Make yourself useful -- Captain.

dialogues.speaker: LEHMANN
dialogues.text: (smiling) Thanks, Captain. Pleased and happy, he busies himself checking instruments

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men on the mooring mast start to disconnect the nose cone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His face against a window, Boerth stands on the long stai leading to the riggers' shelf where Chief Knorr and Secon Rigger Neuhaus disconnect the nose cone from inside.

dialogues.speaker: KNORR
dialogues.text: Eric -- lend a hand. You act like this is your first trip.

dialogues.speaker: BOERTH'S POINT OF VIEW TOWARD GROUND 67
dialogues.text: Freda Hallé regards Boerth with a calm, unwavering gaze.

dialogues.speaker: CLOSE ON BOERTH 68
dialogues.text: He stares at Freda for-a long beat, then turns away.

dialogues.speaker: FREDA 69
dialogues.text: visibly moved. She hurries off, glancing back once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Searchlights playing onto Her sides, she noses from.the m Mooring lines are cast off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Troubled, he peers down, shading his eyes from the beams.

dialogues.speaker: HIS POINT OF VIEW
dialogues.text: She stares back and waves half-heartedly. With his wife a the center, the world slowly recedes.  , de 73 iT

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER AT OBSERVATION WINDOW
dialogues.text: He hangs.on to his wife with his eyes. shoulder. Angle widens as Kessler turns to find Vogel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Kessler. Did you know we're cabin mates?

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Are we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I feel honored. I hope the Colonel doesn't mind sharing quarters with me.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Delighted. But his face doesn't show it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand claps his 73 74 Set adazzle by the searchlights, the Hindenburg floats up silent as a cloud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Navigator von Bauer hands a weather map to Pruss who frow at it.

dialogues.speaker: PRUSS
dialogues.text: Weather over the Channel.

dialogues.speaker: LEHMANN
dialogues.text: (dipping in) If we fly the north side of the storm, the pressure pattern will simply push us over England.

dialogues.speaker: PRUSS
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) The British don't want us over their chimney pots. They'll com- plain to the Foreign Office.

dialogues.speaker: LEHMANN
dialogues.text: The Foreign Office isn't aboard. 2 The engines start with a roar.

dialogues.speaker: PRUSS
dialogues.text: (firmly) I'll do the worrying this trip, Ernst. We'll stay on course and try to outrun the storm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she sails west, the searchlights hold the swastikas on tail. The searchlights cut off. Darkness....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lonely sailor outlines a huge landing circle around the deserted mast with a marker used for tennis courts. . A title: LAKEHURST NAVAL AIR STATION, MAY 3, 2:28 P.M.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At his desk the Commandant of the Naval Air Station, salt astute Commander Charles E. Rosendahl -- the foremost dev oper of American lighter-than-air -- reads: The Literary Digest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knocking on the door nameplate as he comes, Rosendahl's E Lt. Henry Truscott, young, jaunty with a hair-line mousta hustles. in.

dialogues.speaker: TRUSCOTT
dialogues.text: She's on her way, sir. (delivering a cable) Left Frankfurt ten minutes ago, -8:18 by their clock.

dialogues.speaker: ROSENDAHL
dialogues.text: {reading cable) Now we sweat, Hank.

dialogues.speaker: TRUSCOTT
dialogues.text: Yeah...till 6 A.M. Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: ROSENDAHL
dialogues.text: (picking up Digest) Listen to this: 'No voyager on the Hindenburg need fear fire within the ship, etc., etc.'

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED . 79
dialogues.text: a : ROSENDAHL (Cont'd) es (rises, tossing down the Digest) Same magazine that predicted Landon would beat Roosevelt. in thirty-two states.

dialogues.speaker: TRUSCOTT
dialogues.text: That's why I read Ballyhoo -- exclusively.

dialogues.speaker: ROSENDAHL
dialogues.text: (circling) Every time she puts in here it's like opening a Pandora's box. (beat) A booby-trapped Pandora's box. (pausing at model of airship Los Angeles) Remember what happened last time we took this one up?

dialogues.speaker: TRUSCOTT'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Yeah...If we hadn't had helium, we wouldn't be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looms past camera, silvery’ and immense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A figure on the lower catwalk is all but lost in the. dim tunnel through the depths of the interior. Inside the hul the resemblance is closer to a mine far down in the earth than to a mighty skyborne ship floating effortlessly abov it. Only in the narrow separations between the sixteen massive gas cells are there glimpses of the arches, girde webs of-wire that hold the vast structure together. . . 83 CLOSE ON KESSLER s3 moving on the lower catwalk. Surveying the complexity of this enormous maze, he comes to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boerth, carrying a handling-line and tackle, appears from hidden recess and moves noiselessly down the catwalk. Blo his taps Kessler on the back.

dialogues.speaker: BOERTH
dialogues.text: Have you found it, sir?

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: (turning) Found what?

dialogues.speaker: BOERTH
dialogues.text: (looking him in eye) There are no secrets on Zeppelins.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: (staring back) Let's hope not. Now he makes room for Boerth to pass and watches him disa into dimness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Chief Steward Kirsch and Stewardess Imhoff set the tab to lively music over the speakers, Spah enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When do we eat?

dialogues.speaker: KIRSCH
dialogues.text: A light supper will be served at ten, sir. . .

dialogues.speaker: SPAH
dialogues.text: It's important you put me at Mr. —-. Reed Channing's table. I've-been checking on his dog.

dialogues.speaker: KIRSCH
dialogues.text: You shouldn't have been back there, Mr. Spah. It's against regulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . . ‘(tipping him) ° ‘ , : : So don't say anything. Okay, . friend? Kirsch nods and pockets the money. Stewardess Imhof looks after Spah narrowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: se Kessler and Vogel enter. Passing them, Irene joins her at a table.  “ns #02075 30 re 87 CLOSE ON TABLE ra) IRENE (eagerly) Daddy, I've been waiting to tell you. A young man at the airfield « gave me this. ‘ (producing pen) He told me not to ---

dialogues.speaker: BRESLAU
dialogues.text: (with dismay) Where'd you get that?

dialogues.speaker: IRENE
dialogues.text: I'm trying to tell you, Daddy ---

dialogues.speaker: BRESLAU
dialogues.text: (taking pen) Give it to me, dumpling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father's right, Irene. You shouldn't accept gifts from strange

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Mother....

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER AND. VOGEL
dialogues.text: Kessler has been watching Irene and her father. . VOGEL . _ (following his gaze) “She's a pretty little thing. With only 4000 miles to go, I'd better

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: meet her.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: . (from promenade) > : 4100. .

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: We've got 4100 miles to go.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Right. (pointing to windows) Holland.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: KESSLER (Cont'd) (glancing at watch) Nine minutes late, or do you make it ten, Mr. Douglas? Douglas gives him an odd look. Kessler scrutinizes him.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: (approaching; with a bow) Otto Vogel, the ship's photographer. May I borrow the charming young lady tomorrow as a model?

dialogues.speaker: IRENE
dialogues.text: Hey, that's smooth.

dialogues.speaker: BRESLAU
dialogues.text: (rising) I'm going to have a smoke.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: I'll join you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as others leave) Tell me, Mr. Vogel, is there any- body worthwhile on board? I still say the French Line has the best . . society. , ANGLE ON DOOR TO BAR-SMOKING ‘ROOM - "B" DECK 90 Kessler waits for Breslau to pass through the revolving d which serves as an airlock to the pressurized area on the other side. : . INT. BAR-SMOKING ROOM - NIGHT : ‘ : ot

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breslau emerges first into a small alcove with a stand-up Bartender Balla opens a second normal door to admit him t smoking room proper.

dialogues.speaker: BRESLAU
dialogues.text: (as he goes) Thanks. A beer, please. The smoking room, attended by Chief Bar Steward Schulz, h only one lighter, the automobile type, centrally located

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “ns wy 92

dialogues.speaker: SO
dialogues.text: 92 _ He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 91
dialogues.text: awall. Pajetta blows on the lighter and makes a vain atte to ignite his stogie. The Countess fills an elegant minia pipe from a small silver box.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTESS
dialogues.text: (leaning forward) When you're quite through with it, may I, Mr..Pajetta?

dialogues.speaker: PAJETTA
dialogues.text: (peevishly passing it) One damn lighter -- it's hell on cigar smokers.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTESS
dialogues.text: (applying lighter to her little pipe) Filthy habit, cigars. Pajetta sniffs, eyes the Countess, and glances significan Napier who also recognizes the aroma from the little pipe Kessler enters and surveys the smoking room.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTESS
dialogues.text: / (tipping pipe at him) Join me, Colonel? Goering adores it.

dialogues.speaker: STEWARD SCHULZ 92
dialogues.text: opening door to alcove, pointing. :

dialogues.speaker: SCHULZ
dialogues.text: Right in here on the bar. The pen stood upright for more than two hours.. That's how steady the . . « Hindenburg flies. . « Bartender Balla sets a beer in front of Breslau. In b.g. enters. Osborne, an Ivy-leaguer wearing a‘college blazer puffing a carved meerschaum pipe, pretends to play solita while girding himself to approach the Countess.

dialogues.speaker: NAPIER
dialogues.text: Let's have a go at it ourselves, shall we? (looking around) Who has a pen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “ns #02075 33 oN 92 CONTINUED : 92 Napier sees the pen in Breslau's breast. pocket. ‘ "NAPIER , (lifting Breslau's pen) ’ D'you mind, old boy?

dialogues.speaker: BRESLAU
dialogues.text: (jolted) Yes...I need my pen.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER 93
dialogues.text: narrowly watching Breslau.

dialogues.speaker: NAPIER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Not for a few minutes, surely.

dialogues.speaker: BAR-ALCOVE . . 94
dialogues.text: as Napier moves to the bar and stands the pen on it, othe gather around.

dialogues.speaker: . NAPIER
dialogues.text: Fifty quid the bally pen'll be toppled in less than an hour. ay » . BRESLAU « . (reaching for pen) @ This is nonsense. Hobbling over, Pajetta hooks his cane onto Breslau's arm.

dialogues.speaker: PAJETTA
dialogues.text: You haven't finished your beer yet, sir. - (to Napier) I'll take that bet. :

dialogues.speaker: NAPIER
dialogues.text: Righto. Anyone else? Osborne? (indicating blazer crest) You'll defend the honor of old Eli, won't you?

dialogues.speaker: OSBORNE
dialogues.text: (Harvard accent) It's Harvard.

dialogues.speaker: NAPIER
dialogues.text: A hundred, did you say? The gentle- man from Yale bets a hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: OSBORNE
dialogues.text: I didn't say that. .I --- He clams up as the Countess laughs and drifts over langui

dialogues.speaker: COUNTESS
dialogues.text: What shall we bet, Colonel? The honor of the Third Reich also hangs in the balance.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: (closely observing pen) On such a thin thread?

dialogues.speaker: COUNTESS
dialogues.text: Five hundred marks it stands eight hours. (teasing) Will you watch it through the night with me, Colonel?

dialogues.speaker: BRESLAU
dialogues.text: . (reaching to pen) I told you I need it. Kessler grabs the pen and moves swiftly. behind the bar. t

Sorry, all bets are off. He drops the pen into the bar sink and opens it carefully water. He looks, pauses, takes the pen from the water and it in his pocket. The bettors screened off by the bar reg him in mystification. Coming from behind the bar, Kessler grasps Breslau by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Mr. Breslau, please Come with me.

dialogues.speaker: BRESLAU
dialogues.text: What in hell's going on? Kessler hustles him through the door lock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kessler shakes four diamonds from inside the pen onto the writing table. Breslau sits on the bed....

dialogues.speaker: BRESLAU
dialogues.text: ...When they came to me, I refused to do it. They brought it to my daughter anyhow. She didn't know what it was; neither did my wife.

dialogues.speaker: , KESSLER
dialogues.text: Are your relatives Jews?

dialogues.speaker: BRESLAU
dialogues.text: (rising) Damn you, yes! My grandmother was a Jew. Look here, Colonel. I import a lot of German surgical instruments. You can bet the manu- facturers. won't be so sensitive about my grandmother's background.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Mrs. Milstein.

dialogues.speaker: BRESLAU
dialogues.text: Yes. They wanted me to sell the diamonds so they could get out of Germany. Does their name have to co be part of it now? You know what ‘could Happen to them. Kessler shrugs, puts the pen in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: (handing him diamonds, poker-faced) — : Just make sure you declare these to U. S. Customs. 7 (tapping his pocket) I'm keeping the pen for the Gestapo museum. - Kessler leaves. Thunder rumbles outside’ the ship.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE HINDENBURG
dialogues.text: As she flies through a darkening sky, there's a flash of lightning in the distance. °

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i sp-gee\ ce] Lightning, followed by more thunder, slashes past fri “ passengers at the observation windows.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED . 97
dialogues.text: Others hurry from tables in the dining saloon where a lat supper is being served. Rain, sounding like surf, belts d on the linen outer skin. Steward Macher closes a window n Mildred and Irene Breslau. , ,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe Spah occupies a third place at their table for two.

dialogues.speaker: SPAH
dialogues.text: Yeah, when I saw your dog it was doing good. .

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: That was real kind, Joe. Channing pours champagne for Bess, goes to fill Joe's gla

dialogues.speaker: SPAH
dialogues.text: (turning over glass) Never touch the stuff. Nearby lightning flares, followed instantly by a crash of thunder.. Flinching, Channing spills some wine. Spah thru his hand into a napkin, deftly fashions it into a puppet mops up the wine.

dialogues.speaker: CHANNING . '
dialogues.text: (filling own glass) .- It looks like our moment of truth has come.

dialogues.speaker: SPAH
dialogues.text: (making puppet speak) So okay, Mr. Channing. I'm gonna tell you the truth about Joe. He bribed the guy to be at your table. He's a big admirer. But that's not the real reason. . 2 ° (without puppet now; earnestly) The real reason is I'd like to be in your new show, Mr. Channing. I'm working on this new act. A Zep act. Real sophisticated. Per- fect for a show like yours.

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: (transfixed by storm) Sugar, next time let's take the Titanic.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 98
dialogues.text: They can almost hear the next jagged bolt sizzle past, an this time the crash of thunder shakes the ship.

dialogues.speaker: INT, CONTROL GONDOLA
dialogues.text: Rips of lightning outside the darkened gondola elongate t black figures of the men and distort their faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing) Over there, Max.. See it? An opening in the storm.

dialogues.speaker: PRUSS
dialogues.text: (to Helmsman) Alter course 30 degrees right, Frenkel. Head for that light spot.

dialogues.speaker: PRUSS
dialogues.text: (to Chief Sauter) Forward. engines to half. (aside to Lehmann) We'd better slow down in this tur- bulence. That's how your American friends lost all their ships.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE HINDENBURG
dialogues.text: She sails on to. clear skies and starlight. INT. CABIN OF KESSLER AND VOGEL - NIGHT : “103 Kessler on the lower bunk studies the dossier supplied hi the ss. vogel finishes brushing his teeth. _ “yOGEL + . oo That pen incident -- it's obvious you're looking for a bomb. Kessler stares at him coldly.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: (climbing into upper) Only obvious to me, that is. I knew he was the kind for diamonds, not bombs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “ns #02075 38 ro 103 CONTINUED . 103 _) VOGEL (Cont'd) ~ (stretching out) I could've told you Breslau is a Jew. All the characteristics: brachycephalic skull, heavy lower jaw, kinky hair, skin ---

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Breslau happens to be just one- quarter Jewish. Vogel snorts. Kessler turns a page of the dossier.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Only in Berlin is everyone so pure. The world is mongrelized, Vogel. We have all shapes of heads. to choose from here. Can your x-ray eyes see inside them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napier, Pajetta, Osborne, and a business man play cards. tape is missing from the tip of Pajetta's cane.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Major Napier, for one, who has no traceable income, but makes frequent .trips on luxury liners. A good way to pick up information from impor- tant people. Why suddenly the Hindenburg? His big earlobes make me think He's a British spy.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: There's no need for sarcasm, Colonel.. 105 INT,’ "A" DECK PROMENADE - NIGHT . 105 Douglas paces the empty deck. : :

dialogues.speaker: . VOGEL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: May -I humbly suggest’ that Mr. Edward Douglas also bears watching? So very afraid we'll arrive late.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: KS He's head of the foreign branch of BB an advertising company in Berlin. S Their big account is pharmaceuticals.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: KESSLER'S VOICE (Cont'd) But he collected information from German plants that supply parts for the Hindenburg. Douglas swings into the foyer, stops at the progress map studies it. worriedly.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: America prepares for war, too.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: He was Naval Intelligence during the last one. Stayed abroad. Went into advertising. But he's careful not to advertise his business this trip. :

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Joe Spah is just the opposite. He'd do anything to get his name in the paper. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spah does a backbend from the upper - bunk and picks up a object from the floor. The Japanese diplomat in the lower stares at him. Upside down, Spah hands him the horn-rims he's retrieved. The Japanese smiles and bows. Spah bows back, drops all the way and stands on‘his head.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: He's just a clown.  _..

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: A clown who refused to perform for the Fuehrer to be. on this flight. Also he spent a week. in Moscow. To see the Russian circus -- he says. You can't deny Spah has an > unfriendly attitude.

dialogues.speaker: RESSLER'S
dialogues.text: A lot of people fail to see all our endearing qualities.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Which are well displayed in the Countess. How do you happen to know her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Countess moves warily. She is looking for a certain d

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Her husband and I were members of the same flying club in the days before the Luftwaffe. He was killed in a crash and she went back to her family estate. Haven't seen her in years.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Ah, a rich widow with an estate.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Yes, she's from a very distinguished North Baltic family. A von Reugen from Peenemunde.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: - Peenemunde? At the mouth of the Oder?

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Right. She owns half the island.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Countess finds the door she wants, opens it cautiousl Radio Officer Speck sits at the equipment, manicuring his VOGEL'S VOICE. Not any more. Peenemunde's just : een taken over by Weapons Research. Some big new development in rockets. If she knows what's going on there, it's risky letting her out of the = country. Speck senses something, turns. At first he looks surprise then delighted. He beckons her in. ° *KESSLER'S VOICE ‘ , . I'd say it was risky for the ship's photographer to step out of line with the Countess. Speck carefully checks the passageway.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Maybe so, but if I were you, Kessler, I'd find out just how much she really knows before I let her off this ship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door closes.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED . 108
dialogues.text: oY . KESSLER'S VOICE , _/ (annoyed) I intend to. But you stay away from her. 109 INT. CREW'S QUARTERS - NIGHT © 109 As Boerth looks on, Cabin Boy Flakus plays checkers with Mechanic Ludecke. Boerth stops young Flakus from making a move, shows him a good one. Ludecke protests angrily.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (a sarcastic click- ing sound, then) Fine with me. Tomorrow this photog- rapher might take ‘some pictures of © the crew. Find out what the common people are thinking.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: They say the rigger Eric Boerth has a mistress who works in the Berlin branch of a French bank.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: (sitting up) . Where did you hear that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I also hear she's been around. Boerth's not the first. Her name | is Freda Halle.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: I. understand Boerth's a good man, a Hitler Youth troop leader. . . . (beat) . . : By the way, am I a suspect, too? . KESSLER. You? You're my staunch ally, my teammate, my good right arm -- the Gestapo.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: Ridiculous. Where'd you get such an idea?

dialogues.speaker: . KESSLER
dialogues.text: (holding up dossier) Detailed information about everyone but Otto Vogel. All it says about him is 'official Hindenburg photog- rapher.'

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: (smugly) Gestapo sources of information are really excellent.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Maybe not quite so good as you think. (raising dossier) This fails to mention that Colonel Kessler doesn't like Gestapo methods, doesn't use them and -- (tossing notebook into his bunk) I don't want you operating behind my back. . Vogel leans against the linen wall, staring hard at him. Kessler yawns and stretches out on his bunk. oO KESSLER That's why we're cabin-mates. cuT TO

dialogues.speaker: THE BOMB
dialogues.text: held in the same hand, but behind it now is the throb of ship's engines establishing beyond all doubt that the bom aboard the Hindenburg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A title: U.S. STATE DEPARTMENT, TUESDAY, MAY 4, 9 A.M.-

dialogues.speaker: UNDERSECRETARY HANFORD
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Dr. Luther. I hate to think Captain Lehmann will be wast- ing his time here.

dialogues.speaker: LUTHER
dialogues.text: (handing him ’ Rauch letter) Well, perhaps this at least will persuade State to arrange the appointments for him.

dialogues.speaker: . HANFORD
dialogues.text: (as he reads) You know how Congress feels about helium. They're afraid Chancellor Hitler would use it for military --- He stops and finishes the letter with rising concern.

dialogues.speaker: HANFORD
dialogues.text: Good lord, Dr. Luther, what's been >done about this? :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: __ Everything possible to guarantee ~~ the safety of the airship. But the oo chief danger to the Hindenberg is America's monopoly of helium. If anything happens, Mr. Hanford, the catastrophe could be blamed on your country. . yo ‘cur To ~ .

dialogues.text: Sparkling in the sunlight, she cruises above a calm Atlan

dialogues.text: Cabin Boy Flakus advances the little flag to a point 200 off the Irish coast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Entering, Kessler hesitates as he sees the 2nd Radio Offi with Speck. : ‘KESSLER . Mr. Lessing, would you wait outside a moment, please?

dialogues.speaker: LESSING
dialogues.text: Certainly, Colonel. With a sidewise glance at Speck, he leaves.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Get this message off to Gestapo Headquarters, Berlin. Attention Hufschmidt. (dictating to Speck) Send results of Freda Halle sur- veillance so far. Also run check on Halle lovers before Boerth -- signed Kessler. fas Speck finishes typing) Destroy that when it's sent and record the message by code. number.

dialogues.speaker: SPECK
dialogues.text: Yessir. He begins tapping out the message on the wireless key.’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a platform above the middle catwalk, von Bauer shoots sunlines through the plexiglass bubble in the skin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunlight filters through the fabric skin into the shaft. Steward Kirsch; followed by Channing, appears on the lowe catwalk below the shaft. ;

dialogues.speaker: CHANNING
dialogues.text: We don't like the dog so far away. Suppose something happens?

dialogues.speaker: KIRSCH
dialogues.text: Impossible, Mr. Channing. Your dog is traveling first class as good as the passengers. The sound of excited barking comes from a freight room af

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? She agrees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kirschi Kirsch, with a pained expression, stops abruptly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kessler bears down on them.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: What are you doing taking a pas- senger into the ship's interior?

dialogues.speaker: CHANNING
dialogues.text: Just a minute, Colonel. When we bought our tickets we were told we could visit our dog.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: That may be, Mr. Channing, but the ship's interior is now off limits to passengers. (hard at Kirsch) No matter how much’ anyone. tips. . “ igesturing Channing . forward) Now please.... As Channing starts off, the dog o.s. barks loudly.

dialogues.speaker: CHANNING
dialogues.text: ; » (whirling) “Damn it, I'm, going to see my dog. He stumbles trying to get past Kessler who steadies him.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Passengers are barred for their own safety. (pointing down) Take a look, Mr. Channing. If you fell, you'd go right through into the sea. Channing, still furious, glances down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sk 121

dialogues.speaker: PRUSS
dialogues.text: Last year passengers were per- mitted inside the hulI, but not this voyage. Pull back to the Channings who confront Pruss with Kessle beside him.

dialogues.speaker: CHANNING
dialogues.text: (angrily) Typical. You're running the ship . like a concentration camp.

dialogues.speaker: PRUSS
dialogues.text: I agree that I am running this ship. BESS. You can go to hell. No, I take it back. That would be better than Germany is today.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: I'm curious, Mr. and Mrs. Channing. Why would people like yourselves wtake the Hindenburg?

dialogues.speaker: CHANNING
dialogues.text: (heatedly) If you must know, only because my wife. --- . ° Bess stops him with a look.

dialogues.speaker: CHANNING
dialogues.text: -+-My wife gets seasick on boats.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: (smiling at Bess) The Zeppelin Company couldn't have a better recommendation. : ‘PRUSS I'll assign the cabin boy to visit your dog every watch and report back to you. Fair enough?

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: (smiling) Now let's talk about the arrangements for your concert, Mr. Channing.

dialogues.speaker: CHANNING
dialogues.text: D'you really think I'll go through with it now?

dialogues.speaker: PRUSS
dialogues.text: I announced the concert. I'm sure you won't disappoint us.

dialogues.speaker: CHANNING
dialogues.text: (pauses; an edge) Okay. You're the captain. You want a concert -- (spreading his hands) -- there'll be a concert.

dialogues.text: handwritten: “HAWKS TWO BEHIND EARLY STANZAS STOP HOW MUC

dialogues.speaker: LEHMANN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: It's obviously in some private code.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lehmann, Kessler and Speck puzzle over the message. ‘ . KESSLER In any case it requires an answer which:we'll see before Douglas. That gives us an advantage.

dialogues.speaker: LEHMANN
dialogues.text: True. (to Speck) Go ahead and send it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as she is swallowed up in heavy fog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ége The gondola is shrouded in the grey gloom of the fog.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 125
dialogues.text: mT) PRUSS (to Elevatorman) Take her down below the fog layer, Hans. .

dialogues.speaker: LEHMANN
dialogues.text: But no lower than 100 feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kessler pulIls on a sweater and goes into the passageway. stops, sniffs, zeros in on a door he throws open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In elegant deshabille at the writing desk, she applies a lighter to her odd little pipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (between puffs) By all means, come right in, Franz.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Where'd you get that lighter?

dialogues.speaker: COUNTESS
dialogues.text: From our hot-blooded radio operator. a KESSLER , Give it to me, Countess. Twisting away, she sits on the settee (bed made up for da

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: (extending his palm) Behave Ursula. You know it's dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTESS .
dialogues.text: .. - . (lolling back) , : . Franz, I've learned the new game. Breaking all the rules. It's much more fun for people like us than the butchers and shoe clerks in their Brown shirts. Because, you see, we made the rules. Dos KESSLER ap (grasping her wrist) I made this one.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 127
dialogues.text: 7 He pries open her fingers and takes the lighter.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTESS
dialogues.text: -(a weary sigh) Go ahead. Take it. (gesturing) Help yourself to anything else. That's the official policy, isn't it? (shrugging) * They've already taken my house and my land.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: So I heard. A great sacrifice. It was most generous of you.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTESS
dialogues.text: Generous? I screamed bloody mur- der. Good God, if I told you what they're doing at Peenemunde, Franz ---

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: (grasping her shoulders) ~You don't know, Ursula. No one does. If they thought you did, you wouldn't be allowed to leave the country. Listen to me. Without, any questions asked or answered, you miade a great sacrifice for the Fatherland. . (hard emphasis) * Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares at him, then slowly nods.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: (releasing her gently) Good. > “> COUNTESS . (a deliberate trans- formation) Why anyone would want that wretched island, I'1l never know. Did I tell you, Franz, that I've finally gotten rid cf it? (picking up picture of her daughter) Trudi will be delighted, too. She's growing up rather nicely, I think. She'll be at the air- field. Perhaps you'll see her.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Beautiful child. {looking up) I heard you say she's at school in Boston. That's marvelous.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTESS
dialogues.text: Yes, and doing very well there. It's a school for the deaf, you know. The best, I'm told. Trudi's learned to speak now and lip-read. This. summer we'll --- Suddenly she gasps and drops the picture. The cabin has turned an eerie blue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole ship glows the same eerie blue. The passengers tea on the banquettes look in terror at sparks dancing of their fingers. People come running from their cabins and the lounge. Kessler hurries onto the promenade with the Countess who has the white cape over her shoulders.
fo
Pajetta and Napier rush from the lounge. Spotting Kessler Pajetta remembers he's:crippled, pulls up short and leans heavily on his cane.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: having seen. and. well-noted Pajetta's sudden agility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: becoming visible as‘ the Zeppelin descends through the fo + EXCITED VOICES OVER > Pa Were. on fire...It's crashing...I smell gas...Harold!

dialogues.speaker: FULL ON PROMENADE 132
dialogues.text: The sparks stop and the blue glow fades. Lehmann, smiling reassurance, appears on deck.

dialogues.speaker: LEHMANN ,
dialogues.text: Please. Don't be upset. You've just been treated to a harmless display of St. Elmo's fire.

dialogues.speaker: EXCITED VOICES
dialogues.text: What's that?...I know gas when I smell it....

dialogues.speaker: LEHMANN
dialogues.text: (chuckling) No, no, no. As the ship came through the fog, we accumulated an electrical charge -- like a child shuffling his shoes across a carpet. But we're in no danger of conducting the electricity, since we're at an altitude of one hundred feet. Kessler curiously watches Pajetta limping off with Napier

dialogues.speaker: THE COUNTESS . 133
dialogues.text: Drawing her cape around her, she contemplates the sea thr an open window. Kessler stops beside her.

dialogues.speaker: . COUNTESS
dialogues.text: Marvelous sensation on an airship... floating...timeless.... , Kessler inconspicuously tosses the lighter in his hand; t drops it into the sea. She looks at him mischievously.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER _
dialogues.text: Do you still play cards, Ursula? .

dialogues.speaker: . COUNTESS
dialogues.text: (flatly) Why? - : KESSLER ° ; . : . Major Napier and Pajetta. .They . . pique my professional curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTESS
dialogues.text: I've been propositioned frequently, but this is the first time I've been recruited by the Luftwaffe. That is what you're doing, isn't it, Franz?

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Yes...with apologies.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTESS
dialogues.text: (laughing) I'll give you ten percent of my winnings.. If you rememher, I'm good at games of chance,

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: You're in the right place.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTESS
dialogues.text: (a puzzled look) Now that's. an odd thing to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: rearranged for Channing's concert...crowded. Unoccupied r served seats for the Captain are in the front row. Some off-duty crewmen, including Boerth, congregate on the pro decks. Many passengers are in evening dress. At the piano Channing waits for the beautifully gowned Countess to fin seat. Men pop up all over, offering their places, but she settles in splendid isolation in the Captain's row. Chann starts to play.

dialogues.text: »At the back, Kessler nods to Vogel. They quietly slip ou

dialogues.text: Vogel searches through Spah's suitcase. He finds a gun, i spects it...a toy gun...Another doll. He pulls. off the h looking inside. * Nothing but stuffing. He jams the head sticks the doll. in the suitcase and closes it hurriedly some force. A paper flutters off the writing table. He picks it up.

dialogues.text: It bears a sketch of the interior of the Hindenburg's ste

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: He's shown us where to look for his next trick. (handing him case) See if you can open this.

dialogues.text: (disdainfully) Standard combination. Holding the lock to his ear he opens it expertly by using sense of touch and hearing.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: Simple for a man who knows his job. KESSLER . . Mine didn't require picking locks. and layouts for toothpaste ads. .

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Douglas got rid of that airport cable fast. (closing case) We'll. have to wait for the answer to the one he sent. . VOGEL . {glancing at watch) How long is this concert going to last?

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: No telling, but I asked the Captain to arrive fifteen minutes late.

dialogues.text: A coding device. Pull back to Kessler and Vogel. studying the device besid an open backgammon board containing assorted currency. KESSLER . I've never seen one like it. VOGEL. Luftwaffe Intelligence has. been too busy sunning themselves in Spain. He turns the disc until "Operation K" appears in the wind KESSLER . What do you think that stands for, Vogel -- Operation Kraut, Knockwurst, or Kosher? Kessler takes the device, returns it.to the backgammon bo

dialogues.text: What more do you need to arrest Napier and Pajetta?

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: My orders are to move quietly. Be- . sides, when you surface a spy and he doesn't know it, you can use him to your own advantage.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: . (a tight. smile) You go to your church, I'll go to mine --— or should I say synagogue, : . . . Colonel? .

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Some day, Vogel, all that nastiness inside your gut is going to back up and choke you.

Mr. Joe Spah has _ kindly agreed to take part in our little entertainment. (pointedly) I hope you like it, Captain. . As Spah comes from his seat, a ripple of excitement goe : through the audience. , 4

But what Spah dances and pant mimes is a sendup of the Nazis. Produ ing. .props by slei -hand, he turns himself into Hitler, a dive-bombér, an Ar maiden, a goose-stepping Brown Shirt, etc., all performin actions the opposite of what Channing's kindly words desc

dialogues.text: At first there is confused silence, then an undercurrent of whispering. After awhile a few people giggle nervously ‘

dialogues.speaker: THE COUNTESS
dialogues.text: Seated beside the: Captain,. she has her hand to her mout trying desperately to suppress her laughter.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: He throws back his head and laughs outright. Others near now relax and laugh.

dialogues.text: As Kessler's smile widens, Vogel's scowl deepens. Kessler catches himself and glances off toward the crew members. Many are displeased or bewildered.

dialogues.text: Boerth is‘‘smiling. His eyes meet Kessler's.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: He regards, Boerth with a slight lift of his brows.

dialogues.text: She gives way to her laughter, wiping her eyes. Several. officers also Iaugh out of politeness. Pruss freezes them with a look and stands. His officers rise with him. Pruss steps to the piano and gently lowers the cover to stop ; Channing's playing. . -

dialogues.text: halting in mid-act and looking back to see what's happene to the music. When he absorbs the situation, he turns himself into an SS motorcyclist complete with swastikas o the tail. Propelled by his own engine noises, he zooms of 147 148 149 150 151 152— 153 154

dialogues.text: (with an edge) Thank you so much, Mr. Channing. Unfortunately your humor is not the same as ours. Good night, sir.

dialogues.text: You were amused.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Relieved. There's nothing explosive in words: and music.
