(pouring: coffee as Kessler sits). The Gestapo often exaggerates their information. a = A moment” -- ther Kessler lifts the ‘blueprints.

dialogues.speaker: " KESSLER
dialogues.text: You building this? .

dialogues.speaker: LEHMANN
dialogues.text: Yes. My own design for a house in Zeppelinheim, a new village near the airfield. We're hoping -

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 248
dialogues.text: LEHMANN (Cont'd) a lot of our airship families will settle there. ‘A knock...Lessing enters with a radiogram.

dialogues.speaker: LESSING
dialogues.text: For you, Colonel. He delivers it and leaves. Kessler opens the envelope. His face tightens as he reads the message.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: From the Gestapo. Boerth's woman has been arrested. She's confessed her ex-lover was killed fighting with the leftists in Spain.

dialogues.speaker: LEHMANN
dialogues.text: In the hands of the Gestapo anyone can be forced to confess anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And in bed with his mistress, Boerth could have been talked into a plot.

dialogues.speaker: LEHMANN
dialogues.text: “What plot, Colonel? A crank letter has been made into a ‘matter of State. The purpose of exaggerating the bomb scare was to get helium. I went along’ with that. a .

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: There are other sources of in- formation.

dialogues.speaker: LEHMANN
dialogues.text: Perhaps no more valid than the letter.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: I'm no believer in the occult, like our Mrs. Rauch, but I tell you, Captain, I have an uneasy sense of disaster. It's almost as though a bomb were ticking inside me.

dialogues.speaker: LEHMANN
dialogues.text: It's a constant feeling with some people in Germany these days.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: . LEHMANN (Cont'd) A decent man like you, Colonel, with a wife -- probably raising a family -- have you never had this feeling ‘before? . The wall of Kessler's impenetrability cracks. Beneath his surface calm can now be glimpsed a man of iron will force to live between the opposites of his personal creed and t State Philosophy. lLehmann's question draws a bitter resp

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Raising a family. My only son was killed three months ago working for the 'New Order.' And believe me I'm not much better...working with the Gestapo...while their spy lies in the bed above me. Lehmann grimaces and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: LEHMANN
dialogues.text: What's happening to people like us? I've given my life to Zeppelins. For the sake of our company I even dropped political pamphlets last _year, from this ship. Where does it stop?

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: (shaking head) I've been in the Air Force since the World War. When the Versailles Treaty abolished it, I worked with Goering. and the others to. build a secret one.

dialogues.speaker: LEHMANN
dialogues.text: I remember those days. You people trained in gliders. . KESSLER . Yes, all over Germany. Most of the . a time at night. I was proud when Hitler brought the new Luftwaffe into the open. But I wasn't proud last week after Guernica -~ (derisively) -- a little Basque village, a few hundred peasants; three thousand bombs dropped on them. The town was wiped out the first ten minutes -- but we kept it up three hours -- just for the practice.

dialogues.speaker: LEHMANN
dialogues.text: You were there?

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Chief of Intelligence. LEHMANN . That's how one wins the Knight's. Cross in peacetime. -

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER -
dialogues.text: Peacetime.... . LEHMANN. (breaking the moment) Well, now we have two herdes aboard. Boerth did valiant service to the Hindenburg today. He doesn't seem Tike the man to destroy the ship.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: He does to me. He's just the man I'd choose for a dangerous mission. Bold, tough, cool.

dialogues.speaker: LEHMANN
dialogues.text: (slight smile) You have those qualities in common with him. You're both good men.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: ’ Z must get to know him better. (handing Lehmann radiogram) Please“show this to Pruss. (standing) And thanks for the coffee. Good night, Captain. (pauses) I hope you get your house built. . “ : . . . - . INT. HULL ~ NIGHT - NOSE CONE . 249° Dark, silent...Boerth checks mooring lines. Kessler ascen the stairs and joins Boerth on the narrow shelf in the no Boerth regards him quizzically.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Freda Halle has been arrested. Boerth stiffens, but instantly recovers his easy manner.

dialogues.speaker: BOERTH
dialogues.text: Traffic violation?

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: No. . By the Gestapo.

dialogues.speaker: BOERTH
dialogues.text: (contemptuously) Because she works for foreigners?

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Because I think she works with you.

dialogues.speaker: BOERTH
dialogues.text: She lives with me.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: She's admitted your predecessor was killed fighting for the leftists in Spain.

dialogues.speaker: BOERTH
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: If she knows about the bomb, they'll make her confess that too.

dialogues.speaker: BOERTH
dialogues.text: What bomb?

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Where is it, Boerth? They'll be working on Freda until you tell me.

dialogues.speaker: BOERTH
dialogues.text: You filth.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: No worse than the filth who wants to blow up 97 people. But you won't have the chance. I'm locking you up. : , (gripping his arm) You're under arrest.

dialogues.speaker: BOERTH
dialogues.text: (deadly quiet) Kessler, get your hands off.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Let's go. (jerks his arm)

dialogues.speaker: BOERTH
dialogues.text: Get your hands off or I'll blow it up now. You can't stop it. I can do it any second. . A cold, hard ring of truth and conviction in Boerth's voi makes Kessler hesitate; then Boerth whirls to face him an almost pleading, blurts out:

dialogues.speaker: BOERTH
dialogues.text: Don't force me, damn it. Kessler, I need your help. Kessler, amazed, relaxes his grip.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: And you patched her up today to make your own propaganda. No good if she just tumbled into the sea. No politics in an act of God, eh?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 252

dialogues.text: A hydrogen airship? It's cold- blooded murder.

dialogues.speaker: BOERTH
dialogues.text: The Luftwaffe in Spain was cold- blooded murder. But that was just practice for Hitler.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: (sardonically) And you people think you can save the world by blowing up the. Hindenburg. - BOERTH . It's a place to start. (passionately) It will prove there is a Resistance. Decent Germans will get the courage to join us. And no one has to be killed -- if you help me. You're + the key to how ---

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Coming.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: He quickly descends the curving stairs and takes the mess from Lessing on the lower catwalk. He opens the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: BOERTH

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: His face filled with pity, he moves slowly down the catwa folding the message smaller and smaller in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: _ VOGEL
dialogues.text: Have a date’ with my little Jewish model. I'm curious to try one before they're all gone.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: Cologne won't help you.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: _ (erupting) Why didn't you arrest Boerth? Pruss’ showed me the message. > KESSLER . I don't take orders from Hufschmidt or you. (controlling himself) I'm still looking for a bomb. Arrest- ing Boerth won't keep it from going off.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: It will, dammit, if you make him talk.

dialogues.speaker: HN 289 CONTINUED 259
dialogues.text: Cm KESSLER - Your thumbscrews didn't make Freda Halle talk -- (witheringly) -~- before she was 'shot while try- ing to escape.’

dialogues.speaker: . VOGEL
dialogues.text: That was the mistake of some stupid guard, and you're making a worse one. Arrest Boerth, Douglas, Spah -- all of them. Stop dragging your feet.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER

dialogues.text: Nae . “ KESSLER You just do what you're told. [I'11 handle Boerth. You watch Napier and Spah -- and, of course, your little model. ,

dialogues.text: I know, Boerth. I lost my boy in March =~ my only child. Boerth, his back still turned, waits.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER 7 272
dialogues.text: sad and furious at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: He was in the Hitler Youth. Fifteen years old. They went out for some fun one night. Paint slogans on a synagogue... Alfred was on the roof. He slipped and fell. His neck was broken.

dialogues.speaker: BOERTH
dialogues.text: Your son died for Hitler. Damn it, isn't that enough for you?

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: (evenly) Plenty. I don’t need ninety-seven more dead’on this ship.

dialogues.text: Help? To blow up the Zeppelin.

dialogues.speaker: BOERTH
dialogues.text: (passionately) : And, everything she stands for, I . “ , told you, it will happen at the mooring.mast. No one aboard. “My God, that's the last thing I want. Ask Commander Rosendahl for Marines to cordon off the ship. Keep every- one at least fifty yards away.

dialogues.text: Ir would have tq see the bomb first, know how it works.

dialogues.speaker: BOERTH

dialogues.speaker: KESSLER
dialogues.text: I have to see it. Too much can go wrong. «

dialogues.speaker: BOERTH

dialogues.text: Thirteen passengers,. twenty-two members of the crew, and one Navy linesman dead. (a beat) 2 -- On May 12, the day of the Coronation in London, the United States Department of Commerce began ~° a thorough investigation of the Hindenburg disaster. For three weeks a Board of Inquiry heard testimony from all qualified wit- nesses. The twenty-three surviving “passengers had no real information te communicate. The thirty-nine surviving crew members added little more.
